posts.cooked:
Currently, I am trying to write code that makes our robot leave the tarmac and then shoot the preloaded cargo via a sequential command group. Currently, for some reason, the code is causing the robot to go straight to the shooting, forgoing leaving the tarmac. Does anyone know why this is? Thanks

Don’t see an error right away, but to debug I would look into the isFinished() of your autocross command. Maybe print the position out in there.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: A number of teams have run into an issue where if you’re using CAN encoders (e.g. ones integrated into the motor controllers), resetting those encoders does not immediately result in a 0 return value from a subsequent get encoder value call, as it takes time for the message to propagate through the CAN bus command and telemetry path.  To avoid this, instead of using the reset encoder call, you can store an offset and subtract it.

I don’t know if it’s causing your bug, but a style comment: In setDriveSpeed_Arcade, you set xSpeed and zRotation (expecting to set the object’s member variable), but then proceed to refer to them as ‘xSpeed’ and ‘zRotation’. I’m not certain if it will use the passed in value or the member variable value, and whether or not the member variable ever actually gets set. I suggest using this.xxxx or naming the member variable something like m_xSpeed.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Good catch, without using this.xxxx, the member variables aren’t getting assigned.  The yellow squiggly is warning about that I’m sure (it’s a self-assignment).

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Yep.  this is why I encourage m_xxxx for member variables, to avoid any confusion.  I know some don’t like the prefixing but it does cut down on hard to see errors like this.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Yes, it’s also the reason we have m_ prefixes as a style requirement in WPILib!

posts.name: system
